facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 60 of 1958 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 19th February 1958 of Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Writ Petition No. 53 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the, 19th February 1958, of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court, in Writ Petition No. 53 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 10, 1959 by Wanchoo J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. September 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-

facts.text: Certificate granted under Article 132 of Constitution by Jammu and Kashmir High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on a certificate granted under Art. 132 of the Constitution of India  hereinafter called the Constitution  by the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir,

facts.text: Appellants prosecuted before Special Court constituted under Enemy Agents Ordinance for offences under s.3 of Ordinance, ss.3,4,5 Explosive Substances Act, s.120B Penal Code, s.29 Public Security Act r/w rr.28,32.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are being prosecuted before a Special Court companystituted under the Ordinance for offences under s. 3 of the Ordinance, ss. 3, 4 and 5 of the Explosive Substances Act,  VI of 1908 , s. 120-B of the Penal Code and s. 29 of the Public Security Act read with rr. 28 and 32 of the Rules thereunder.

facts.text: Incidents out of which prosecution arose took place on June 27 and 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The incidents out of which this prosecution arose took place on June 27 and 28, 1957.

facts.text: Outside raiders began attacking Kashmir on October 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstances in which the Ordinance came to be passed were these Outside raiders began attacking Kashmir on October 22, 1947.

facts.text: State acceded to India on October 26, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The State acceded to India on October 26, 1947.

facts.text: Enemy Agents Ordinance No. XIX of S. 2004 enacted soon after in January 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Enemy Agents Ordinance, No. XIX of S. 2004 was enacted soon after in January 1948.

facts.text: Cease-fire on January 1, 1949 and raids came to an end.

anchor.surface_text: There was cease-fire on January 1, 1949 and the raids came to an end.

facts.text: Present Enemy Agents Ordinance No. VIII of S. 2005 became law on January 24, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by the present Ordinance which became law an January 24, 1949.

facts.text: Ordinance promulgated by His Highness under s.5 of Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act S.1996.

anchor.surface_text: raises the companystitutionality of the Enemy Agents Ordinance , No. VIII of S. 2005 hereinafter called the Ordinance , promulgated by His Highness under s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act, S. 1996,

facts.text: High Court dismissed the writ petition filed by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, dismissed the writ petition filed by the appellants.

facts.text: High Court held Ordinance not hit by Art.14 due to reasonable classification.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that there was a reasonable classification and that the classification was founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguished persons or things that were grouped together from those left out of the group and the differentia had a rational relation with the object sought to be achieved by the Ordinance. It therefore held that the Ordinance was number hit by Art. 14.

facts.text: Section 5 of Constitution-Act repealed by amending Act No. XVII of S.2005 on November 17, 1951.

issues.text: Whether the Ordinance is unconstitutional and void by reason of the violation of Art. 14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance is unconstitutional as it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether His Highness had legislative competence to promulgate the Ordinance under s. 5 of the Constitution-Act given the Instrument of Accession?

anchor.surface_text: There was no legislative competence in His Highness to issue the Ordinance under s. 5 of the Constitution Act, as His Highness had executed the Instrument of Accession on October 26, 1947 surrendering his powers regarding Defence, Communications and External Affairs to the Government of India and the Ordinance came under the head Defence.

issues.text: Whether the Ordinance came to an end upon the repeal of s. 5 of the Constitution-Act?

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the Constitution-Act was repealed by an amending Act, No. XVII of S. 2005, passed on November 17, 1951, and therefore the Ordinance also came to an end on the day s. 5 was repealed.

issues.text: Whether the Ordinance has lapsed as the conditions under which it was enacted had become obsolete and did not exist any more?

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance has in any case lapsed as the conditions under which it was enacted had become obsolete and did not exist any more.

issues.text: Whether the Ordinance was void as it was inconsistent with Art. 352 of the Constitution and the Articles following?

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance was void as it was inconsistent with Art. 352 of the Constitution and the Articles following.

issues.text: Whether s. 4(1) of the Ordinance is hit by Art. 20(1) of the Constitution?
Whether s. 11(1) of the Ordinance is hit by Art. 22(1) of the Constitution?
Whether the Special Judge has jurisdiction to try an offence under the Explosive Substances Act?
Whether the Ordinance was unconstitutional and void by reason of the violation of Art. 14 of the Constitution?

arguments.claim: High Court held His Highness had competence as State retained concurrent power on ceded subjects if not repugnant to Central law.

anchor.surface_text: It was further of the view that His Highness had legislative competence to promulgate the Ordinance when he did so and that when certain subjects were made over to the Government of India by the Instrument of Accession, the State retained its powers to legislate even on these subjects so long as the State law was not repugnant to any law made by the Central Legislature, thus holding that there was concurrent power in the State to legislate even on the subjects transferred to the Government of India.

arguments.claim: Art.14 forbids class legislation but permits reasonable classification based on intelligible differentia with rational nexus to object; applies to procedure.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution have come up for discussion before this Court in a number of cases. It is now well established that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and, (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: Classification of enemy agents and acts to aid enemy is reasonable with nexus to preventing subversion.

anchor.surface_text: In order, however, to pass the test of permissible classification two conditions must be fulfilled, namely (i) that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and, (ii) that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

arguments.claim: Pith and substance of Ordinance is public order and criminal law/procedure, not Defence.

arguments.claim: Ordinance saved by s.6(b) General Clauses Act despite repeal of s.5 Constitution-Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Ordinance did not come to an end on the repeal of s. 5 of the Constitution-Act and remained a valid piece of legislation in view of s. 6(b) of the Jammu and Kashmir General Clauses Act.

holdings.text: The Ordinance cannot be said to be discriminatory and, therefore, violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that on the principles laid down by this Court in the large number of cases summarised in the Dalmia case  1 , the Ordinance cannot be said to be discriminatory and, therefore, violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies twin test of reasonable classification under Art.14: intelligible differentia distinguishing enemy agents and acts aiding enemy from others, with rational relation to object of preventing subversion of government; test applies to procedural laws; special procedure justified for new aggravated offence under s.3; follows precedents in Dalmia case.

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that the Ordinance was beyond the legislative competence of His Highness because certain matters were ceded in the Instrument of Accession dated October 26, 1947, to the Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that there is no force in the contention that the Ordinance was beyond the legislative competence of His Highness because certain matters were ceded in the Instrument of Accession dated October 26, 1947, to the Government of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance of Ordinance is public order, criminal law and procedure, not Defence under item 1 of Schedule to Instrument of Accession; indirect impact on armed forces operations in s.3 does not change pith and substance; assumes arguendo no concurrent legislative power.

holdings.text: The Ordinance did not come to an end on the repeal of s. 5 of the Constitution-Act and remained a valid piece of legislation in view of s. 6(b) of the Jammu and Kashmir General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Ordinance did not come to an end on the repeal of s. 5 of the Constitution-Act and remained a valid piece of legislation in view of s. 6(b) of the Jammu and Kashmir General Clauses Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(b) J&K General Clauses Act saves previous operation of repealed enactment and things duly done thereunder; promulgation under s.5 was duly done; law continues unless inconsistent with amended Constitution-Act.

holdings.text: The Ordinance must be held to be in force till such repeal even if the conditions now are assumed not to be exactly the same as in 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Being a permanent law, it can only be brought to an end by means of repeal by competent authority. It is not the case of the appellants that the Ordinance has been repealed by any competent authority. It must therefore be held to be in force till such repeal even if the conditions now are assumed not to be exactly the same as in 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance is permanent legislation targeting deeper evil of subversion with enemies, not temporary; occasion was emergency but continues till repealed; changed conditions do not cause lapse.

holdings.text: Art. 352 and the subsequent Articles in Part XVIII of the Constitution relating to Emergency Provisions have nothing whatsoever to do with the validity or otherwise of the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that the Ordinance was unconstitutional because it is inconsistent with Art. 352 and the subsequent Articles. We must say that Art. 352 and the subsequent Articles in Part XVIII of the Constitution relating to Emergency Provisions have nothing whatsoever to do with the validity or otherwise of the Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No inconsistency between Ordinance and Part XVIII Emergency Provisions.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that there is no force in the contention that the Ordinance was beyond the legislative competence of His Highness because certain matters were ceded in the Instrument of Accession dated October 26, 1947, to the Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the Ordinance did not come to an end on the repeal of s. 5 of the Constitution-Act and remained a valid piece of legislation in view of s. 6(b) of the Jammu and Kashmir General Clauses Act.
It, therefore, dismissed the writ petition filed by the appellants.

Being a permanent law, it can only be brought to an end by means of repeal by competent authority. It is not the case of the appellants that the Ordinance has been repealed by any competent authority. It must therefore be held to be in force till such repeal even if the conditions now are assumed not to be exactly the same as in 1949.
It, therefore, dismissed the writ petition filed by the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged that the Ordinance was unconstitutional because it is inconsistent with Art. 352 and the subsequent Articles. We must say that Art. 352 and the subsequent Articles in Part XVIII of the Constitution relating to Emergency Provisions have nothing whatsoever to do with the validity or otherwise of the Ordinance.
It, therefore, dismissed the writ petition filed by the appellants.
